I wanted to add: After looking closely at "Generation 0" in that 
clip, it's pretty clear there is some kind of constraint.  Even this 
flailing body on the ground is alternating its legs, albeit in an 
unproductive way.  But how can that alternation be present at 
generation 0?  Obviously they somehow forced it that way.  I think 
it's pretty exciting because I doubt they have the same quality 
neuroevolution technology as NEAT, which suggests that the problem 
actually isn't that hard given the right constraints, which implies 
Tyler could possibly evolve even more sophisticated behaviors than 
these guys have.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> Wow, that's pretty nice!  Did you see the demo of their evolution:
> 
> http://www.naturalmotion.com/pages/technology_hiw.htm
> 
> It's very strange that it's walking well after only 20 
generations.  
> It makes you wonder what constraints they put in there.  However, 
it 
> does show this pursuit is feasible.  But it clearly needs the 
right 
> joint controls, fitness function, and possible constraints.  For 
> example, maybe it must be impossible for it to move both legs 
> forward at the same time?
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "ai_junkie_dot_com" <fup@a...> wrote:
> > I think you guys might be interested in taking a look at this:
> > 
> > http://www.naturalmotion.com/
> > 
> > They have had considerable success with evolving human motion. 
> There's
> > not a lot to read but you'll enjoy watching the demos.
